إذا كنت تبحث عن أغنية أخرى بعنوان "زوروا الحبيب"، فقد تكون تشير إلى نشيد ديني يتحدث عن زيارة النبي محمد (صلى الله عليه وسلم). ومع ذلك، لا توجد معلومات محددة حول أغنية بهذا العنوان في المصادر المتاحة.

The song "زوروني كل سنة مرة" ("Visit Me Once a Year") was both written and composed by the Egyptian musician **Sayed Darwish**. He is widely regarded as a pioneer of modern Arabic music. The song has been performed by numerous artists, including the renowned Lebanese singer Fairuz.

The lyrics express longing and yearning, with the singer pleading for loved ones to visit at least once a year to keep the bond alive and prevent the love from fading away.

The original religious poem you are referring to is believed to be **"Zuru Al-Habib"** or **"Zur Qabr Al-Habib Marrah"**, which translates to *"Visit the Beloved's Grave Once"*. 

It is widely attributed to **Mulla Osman Al-Mawsili**, an Iraqi musician, poet, and Sufi scholar. Mulla Osman Al-Mawsili was known for composing and spreading religious and traditional melodies throughout the Arab and Ottoman regions in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

Some historical sources suggest that the famous Egyptian composer **Sayed Darwish** may have adapted the melody of **"Zuru Al-Habib"** when composing *"Zorouni Kol Sana Marrah"* (Visit Me Once a Year), transforming it into a secular song about longing and remembrance. However, this remains a debated topic among historians and musicologists.

If you are looking for a performance of the original religious song, you can find renditions by various Sufi and Islamic vocalists, often performed in praise of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

الشيخ إبراهيم فى المؤتمرْ      وفى مقام الحج والمعتمرْ

وفى مقامه وفى مروةٍ         وفى الصفا وفى استلام الحجر

فالمشعر الحرام فى ليلِهِ        وفى منىً أيام رمي الجِمَرْ

وفى المدينة وأرجائها         فذي الحليفة فبدرٍ قمرْ

والشيخ إبراهيم أيضا قمر    فى مصر والشام ومُدنٍ أخر

يُقيم أو يمر نورُ الهدى       حيث أقام الشيخ أو حيث مر

يقبس أهل البدو من نوره    ومنه يقتبس أهل الحضر

وجوده شذرْ مذرْ فى الورى   يكاد فيهم عاذلا لايذر

وعلمه أيضا شذرْ فيهم       مذرْ كما الجودُ شذرْ أو مذرْ

وإن يقمْ فيهم خطيبا يقلْ    ما يُخجل التبر ويُخزي الدرر

من خُطبٍ فى القلب ولاَّجةٍ    ما لا تَوَلَّجٌ حِدادُ الإبر

فى دعوةٍ إلى سبيل الهدى    يهدي بها الله قُلوب البشر

لا يسمعُ الشيطانُ إلقائها     إلا َّوأدبر وولى وفر

تَوجَّهُ الجموعُ تلقائها      عفواً وتنساقُ إليها الزُّمر

تُصغي إليها شذرةً شذرةً    تشنف الآذان بتلك الشذر

وحظ واعِها وقُرائها       نورُ البصيرة ونور البصر

فيصبحُ الفاجر من فضلها     براً ويُمسي البر يُدعى الأبر

This is a **praise poem** written by the **Mauritanian scholar and historian Al-Mukhtar Walad Hamed**, in honor of **Shaykh Ibrahim Niasse**, a prominent figure in the **Tijani Sufi order**.

### **Translation (Summary):**
The poem describes **Shaykh Ibrahim Niasse** as a guiding light of Islam, emphasizing his presence and influence in various sacred places such as **Mecca, Medina, and other regions** where he traveled. It highlights how his teachings and wisdom reach both **nomads and settled people**, illuminating their hearts and guiding them to the path of righteousness.

It praises his **eloquence in speech**, stating that even **Satan flees upon hearing his sermons**. The poem speaks of **his generosity, knowledge, and piety**, comparing him to historical figures like **Umar ibn Al-Khattab in his fear of God** and **Ali ibn Abi Talib in his virtue**.

The poet also recounts his own personal experiences with Shaykh Ibrahim, expressing gratitude for his blessings and guidance. He acknowledges that merely seeing him **eliminates doubts and fulfills spiritual needs**.

The concluding verses **pray for the Shaykh’s continued guidance**, asking for his influence to endure and benefit the people.

### **Significance:**
This poem reflects the **deep reverence** held for Shaykh Ibrahim Niasse, particularly among followers of **Tijani Sufism**. It aligns with the tradition of **Sufi poetry**, where scholars and poets compose verses exalting spiritual figures and their role in spreading divine wisdom.

### **Translation and Context of the Poem by Al-Mukhtar Walad Hamed in Praise of Shaykh Ibrahim Niasse**  

This poem is a deeply **reverent and devotional praise** of **Shaykh Ibrahim Niasse**, a prominent Sufi leader and scholar, by the **Mauritanian historian and scholar Al-Mukhtar Walad Hamed**. The poem reflects the poet’s admiration and spiritual devotion, highlighting **Shaykh Ibrahim's widespread influence, wisdom, and divine light**. It conveys the poet's gratitude and recognition of the Shaykh’s role in guiding people toward **truth, righteousness, and enlightenment**.

---

### **English Translation (Poetic and Thematic Interpretation)**  

#### **The Universal Presence of Shaykh Ibrahim**  

Shaykh Ibrahim is present **at every gathering**,  
In the sacred pilgrimage, among the faithful who come.  

He stands at **Marwah, at Safa, at the Black Stone**,  
Where prayers are whispered and hearts are won.  

He is seen **in the Sacred Valley by night**,  
In **Mina, among the stones of ritual might**.  

And in **Medina’s holy streets he walks**,  
In Dhul-Hulayfa, in Badr, where history talks.  

#### **A Guiding Light Beyond Borders**  

Shaykh Ibrahim is also a **radiant moon**,  
Shining over **Egypt, Sham, and lands beyond**.  

Wherever he dwells, wherever he treads,  
**The light of guidance follows his steps.**  

The **nomads draw from his radiant glow**,  
And from his wisdom, **the settled folk know**.  

#### **A Man of Unmatched Generosity and Knowledge**  

His **presence is scattered like scattered pearls**,  
A beacon to all, even the most skeptical souls.  

His **knowledge, like his generosity, spreads**,  
Filling the world with riches unsaid.  

Should he **rise to speak**, his words would shame,  
The finest gold and the rarest gems.  

His **sermons penetrate hearts like steel**,  
Sharper than needles, their truth revealed.  

#### **A Call to Truth That Even the Devil Fears**  

He **calls to the path of righteousness**,  
Guiding hearts to divine consciousness.  

Even **Satan flees his mighty words**,  
Turning back, defeated, unheard.  

The **masses rush to hear his voice**,  
Drawn by love, they gather by choice.  

Each word like **a shimmering light**,  
Illuminating hearts and granting sight.  

Those **who listen and understand**,  
Find wisdom’s **touch on both eye and hand**.  

Even the sinner, touched by grace,  
Becomes **a saint in newfound faith**.  

#### **A Spiritual Heir to the Greats**  

O **heir of Umar’s holy fear**,  
And **Ali’s virtue, pure and clear**.  

You tread the path of those before,  
Until you reach the **certainty’s shore**.  

O **joy of the age, its finest gem**,  
Brighter than any **tree’s diadem**.  

Your **gifts and grace revive our nights**,  
Filling them with **heavenly lights**.  

The **nomads and villagers know your name**,  
A presence both eternal and plain.  

#### **A Journey Through Time and Devotion**  

In **Kāolack, your kindness grew**,  
A habit formed, a path renewed.  

I once sought favors from many men,  
From Zayd, from ‘Umar, again and again.  

But then I said, **God suffices for all**,  
And He granted wealth **without withdrawal**.  

For one alone stood in the place of ten,  
And one in ten was found again.  

Now that I’ve seen you here today,  
No longer do I **follow past traces away**.  

Whoever comes seeking your face,  
Finds his **wish fulfilled by grace**.  

Whoever aids you in **righteous cause**,  
Shall find himself **strengthened in laws**.  

May **God sustain you, guide, and bless**,  
And **may your legacy forever progress**.  

---

### **Why This Poem Meant So Much to the Poet (M.Y Kabara's Perspective)**  

This poem is **more than just praise**; it is a **testament of devotion, gratitude, and recognition**. It reflects the deep **love and reverence** many scholars and disciples had for **Shaykh Ibrahim Niasse**, who was seen as **a divine guide, a light of knowledge, and a spiritual beacon** across Africa and beyond.  

For **M.Y. Kabara and many others**, Shaykh Ibrahim’s presence was not just physical—it was **a spiritual force that illuminated hearts, restored faith, and uplifted communities**.  

The poet’s **personal experiences** with the Shaykh, especially in **Kaolack (Senegal, the Shaykh’s center of learning)**, reveal how **a single encounter with a true saint could change a person’s life forever**. The poet acknowledges that he once sought blessings from many, but upon meeting Shaykh Ibrahim, he **found a singular source of divine wisdom and abundance**.  

This poem, therefore, is **not just admiration—it is a testament to a transformative experience, an encounter with true spiritual greatness**. It is a **love letter to a guide who brought light to the poet’s life and the lives of countless others**.
